title: 106_hr191
content: PROTECTING THE INTEGRITY OF THE SOCIAL SECURITY ACCOUNT NUMBER CARD. Improvements to the physical design, technical specifications, and materials of the social security account number card are necessary to enhance security against counterfeiting, forgery, alteration, and misuse. The card should be as secure as the 100 dollar Federal Reserve note in terms of counterfeit detection. Beginning January 1, 2002, all social security account number cards issued must be as secure as a United States passport. Starting January 1, 2008, a secured social security account number card can be used for employment verification. The text chunk discusses the requirements for secured social security cards, emphasizing that they are not national identification cards and do not authorize new databases. It also mentions an education campaign for employers on detecting counterfeit cards and the submission of annual reports on the progress of developing secured social security cards. The text discusses the progress in developing secured social security cards, addressing counterfeit production and fraud prevention measures. The Comptroller General conducts annual audits on the Social Security Administration's performance in meeting these requirements. No additional costs for card development above standard expenses will be covered by the Trust Fund. Authorized appropriations for this section will cover necessary expenses. SEC. 2.
